<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_file_write_:
```c
static lfs_ssize_t lfs_file_write_(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_file_t *file,
        const void *buffer, lfs_size_t size) {
    LFS_ASSERT((file->flags & LFS_O_WRONLY) == LFS_O_WRONLY);

    if (file->flags & LFS_F_READING) {
        // drop any reads
        int err = lfs_file_flush(lfs, file);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }
    }

    if ((file->flags & LFS_O_APPEND) && file->pos < file->ctz.size) {
        file->pos = file->ctz.size;
    }

    if (file->pos + size > lfs->file_max) {
        // Larger than file limit?
        return LFS_ERR_FBIG;
    }

    if (!(file->flags & LFS_F_WRITING) && file->pos > file->ctz.size) {
        // fill with zeros
        lfs_off_t pos = file->pos;
        file->pos = file->ctz.size;

        while (file->pos < pos) {
            lfs_ssize_t res = lfs_file_flushedwrite(lfs, file, &(uint8_t){0}, 1);
            if (res < 0) {
                return res;
            }
        }
    }

    lfs_ssize_t nsize = lfs_file_flushedwrite(lfs, file, buffer, size);
    if (nsize < 0) {
        return nsize;
    }

    file->flags &= ~LFS_F_ERRED;
    return nsize;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (file->pos + size > lfs->file_max) {
        // Larger than file limit?
        return LFS_ERR_FBIG;
    }
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the conditional return is a runtime check and does not make subsequent code unreachable. The branch may or may not execute depending on file->pos and size, so there is no unreachable code introduced by this fragment. (A Rule 2.1 violation would occur only if the condition were provably always true or always false—e.g. if file->pos, size and lfs->file_max were compile-time constants such that file->pos + size > lfs->file_max is always true, making code after the return unreachable.)
